intro: Fumaria barnolae subsp. algerica, commonly known as Algerian celandine, is a flowering plant belonging to the poppy family, Papaveraceae. It is characterized by its delicate, yellowish-orange flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant typically grows in rocky or dry soils, often in Mediterranean climates. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and branched. This subspecies is native to North Africa and is valued for its ornamental appeal and historical use in traditional medicine.
